text: a patch has been put to <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/5139/>. Please have a look.
<@U0KPFAZNF> <@U1AU8DRQR> <@U0MT4CBHB> <@U0PB67X4K> <@U11MANG9G> <@U0KN2SSKE> <@U0XPR4NP4> <@U0TFEHX8E> <@U0ULK2JPP> <@U0ZJZBJLF> Gari and I were discussing how we handle our documentation

one approach we considered was create a fabric-docs project that was effectively a shell repo that links in submodules of the other project repos to create an aggregate repo that we could use to build the aggregate RTD
<@U0UHG4VP1> did some investigation and opendaylight uses this approach

attachments.title: opendaylight/docs
attachments.text: Mirror of the OpenDaylight docs gerrit project

text: I think that it would make sense for us to pursue the same approach
<@U0UHG4VP1> is going to incorporate the git submodule plugin for Gerrit, and once that is available, we should be able to start the process of establishing the fabric-docs project
all we need is a bunch of +1s from the maintainers to do this
<@U0KM61BCP> it makes sense, but submodules can be tricky
<@U0KRRM29Z> and I managed a project that was based on them, and it can get messy
not saying we shouldnt do it this way, but be warned
there will def be confused users
<@U0KPFAZNF> yes, they can be, but this is pretty straight forward

I've never used submodules myself, but <@U0XKW9PV5> has suggested careful evaluation before using them based on his experience with cpp-ethereum <https://lists.hyperledger.org/pipermail/hyperledger-fabric/2016-July/000167.html>. He lists some good points/questions at <https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/hyperledger-fabric/2016-September/000320.html>. I’m not sure if these pre-cautions would apply to a docs only repo.
